indications: Indications oedema, hypertension (see also notes above)
name: XIPAMIDE
cautions:
Cautions 
(From 2.2.1 Thiazides and related diuretics: British National Formulary)
Cautions See also section 2.2. Thiazides and related diuretics can exacerbate diabetes, gout, and systemic lupus erythematosus. Electrolytes should be monitored, particularly with high doses, long-term use, or in renal impairment. Thiazides and related diuretics should also be used with caution in nephrotic syndrome, hyperaldosteronism, and malnourishment; interactions: Appendix 1 (diuretics); also acute porphyria (%s
(From 9.8.2 Acute porphyrias: British National Formulary)
9.8.2 Acute porphyrias)
side-effects:
Side-effects 
(From 2.2.1 Thiazides and related diuretics: British National Formulary)
Side-effects Side-effects of thiazides and related diuretics include mild gastro-intestinal disturbances, postural hypotension, altered plasma-lipid concentrations, metabolic and electrolyte disturbances including hypokalaemia (see also notes above), hyponatraemia, hypomagnesaemia, hypercalcaemia, hyperglycaemia, hypochloraemic alkalosis, hyperuricaemia, and gout. Less common side-effects include blood disorders such as agranulocytosis, leucopenia, and thrombocytopenia, and impotence. Pancreatitis, intrahepatic cholestasis, cardiac arrhythmias, headache, dizziness, paraesthesia, visual disturbances, and hypersensitivity reactions (including pneumonitis, pulmonary oedema, photosensitivity, and severe skin reactions) have also been reported.
doses:
Oedema, initially 40 mg daily in the morning, increased
to 80 mg in resistant cases; maintenance 20 mg in the morning
Hypertension, 20 mg daily in the morning
pregnancy:
Pregnancy 
(From 2.2.1 Thiazides and related diuretics: British National Formulary)
Pregnancy Thiazides and related diuretics should not be used to treat gestational hypertension. They may cause neonatal thrombocytopenia, bone marrow suppression, jaundice, electrolyte disturbances, and hypoglycaemia; placental perfusion may also be reduced. Stimulation of labour, uterine inertia, and meconium staining have also been reported.
